aws::graph::propositions: # Pasadena Police Department Benedict Heliport Accident Information
Pasadena PD–Benedict Heliport was established in 1972.
Pasadena PD–Benedict Heliport was situated on a mesa that overlooks the 210 freeway in Altadena, California.
Pasadena PD–Benedict Heliport was not a certificated heliport.
Pasadena PD–Benedict Heliport was built prior to California Department of Transportation Division of Aeronautics requirements.
Pasadena PD–Benedict Heliport had received an exempt status.
California Department of Transportation sent a letter dated July 13, 1979.
In January 1973, the heliport was designated under the classification of "public safety agencies".
The heliport was exempted from the Department of Aeronautics heliport regulations.
The heliport was deemed exempt and could continue to operate as such.
The Officer in Charge of the air unit responded to the letter submitted by the Department of Transportation.
The city chose not to pursue the matter with the Department of Transportation.
The helicopter accident was recorded on video.
The recorded video showed that N96BM was moved out of the hangar toward Pad 1.
Helicopter N96BM was parked to the west and outside of the painted square that denoted Pad 1.
Helicopter N96BM was positioned between Pad 1 and Pad 2 facing south.
The distance between the outside of Pad 1 to the outside of Pad 2 was 33 feet.
The distance was measured by a total station provided by the Pasadena Police Department.
After the impact, both helicopters came to rest upright.
After the impact, there was minimal displacement/movement of each helicopter.
Helicopter N911FA came to rest facing toward the northeast.
Helicopter N911FA came to rest mostly inside of Pad 2.
A portion of the aft skid of N911FA came to rest outside of the Pad 2 box.
Helicopter N96BM remained to the west of Pad 1 after impact.
The transmission and main rotor blades separated from helicopter N96BM.
The transmission and main rotor blades of N96BM came to rest adjacent to the helicopter.
The main rotor blades of helicopter N911FA separated from the transmission.
The main rotor blades of N911FA came to rest about 10 feet forward and to the left of the helicopter.
The main rotor blades of N911FA came to rest directly behind N96BM.
The transmission for helicopter N911FA remained attached to and inside the helicopter in its relative normal position.

text:
# AIRPORT INFORMATION

The Pasadena PD–Benedict Heliport was established in 1972; it was situated on a mesa that overlooks the 210 freeway in Altadena, California. The heliport was not a certificated heliport as it was built prior to California Department of Transportation (DOT) Division of Aeronautics requirements; as such, it had received an exempt status.

According to a letter from the California DOT, dated July 13, 1979, in January of 1973, the heliport was designated under the classification of "public safety agencies," and will be exempted from the Department of Aeronautics heliport regulations. It was deemed that the heliport was exempt, and could continue to operate as such.

The OIC (Officer in Charge) of the air unit responded to the letter submitted by the DOT and the city chose not to pursue that.

## WRECKAGE AND IMPACT INFORMATION

On-scene documentation was conducted. The accident had been recorded on video. The recorded video showed that N96BM was moved out of the hangar toward Pad 1. The helicopter was parked to the west and outside of the painted square that denoted Pad 1, which placed N96BM in-between Pad 1 and Pad 2 facing south.

The distance between the outside of Pad 1 to the outside of Pad 2 was 33 feet, as measured by a total station provided by the Pasadena Police Department.

After the impact, both helicopters came to rest upright, with minimal displacement/movement of each helicopter. N911FA came to rest facing toward the northeast, and mostly inside of Pad 2; a portion of the aft skid came to rest outside of the Pad 2 box. N96BM remained to the west of Pad 1.

The transmission and main rotor blades separated from N96BM, and came to rest adjacent to the helicopter. The main rotor blades of N911FA separated from the transmission, and came to rest about 10 feet forward and to the left of the helicopter; directly behind N96BM. The transmission for N911FA remained attached to and inside the helicopter in its relative normal position.
